threads.com:
Here's a great idea you teutonic autists.

Instead of mating two engines to the same crankshaft because you don't want the aerodynamic drag associated with four engine nacelles, why not mount one engine as a pusher prop and the other as a tractor prop on the same nacelle? And increase the circumference of the rear prop in order to accommodate for the prop wash of the one in front of it?

Why were the Krauts so retarded when it came to strategic bombers? Even the Soviets had the Pe-8. You may not think it's a big deal but the ability to bomb German industry and not be bombed in return was a big part of what won the allies the war. How come Germany could build the Me-262 but they couldn't manage a decent four engine bomber?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
On top of the already mentioned efficiency problems:

A bomber needs as much open space inside the fuselage as possible, because you want a large bomb bay able to take many (and large) bombs. And there's already lots of other stuff you have to put there, like a bombardier's station, radios, a large crew and so on.

Also, in WW2, you really want a rear-facing gun, or better multiple guns. A big propeller at the rear of the fuselage will create a huge blind spot whole squadrons of fighters could hide in. Even for guns placed in turrets along the fuselage.

>>56247862
The Schnellbomber concept was arguably a success, and it didn't preclude also having strategic bombers. They're not mutually exclusive, most countries had both fast low-altitude medium bombers and high-altitude strategic bombers at the time.

What makes it even more infuriating is that doctrinally, they attempted strategic bombing with the V-1 and V-2 programs, which, while they undoubtedly influenced rocketry for decades, were shitty weapons that were both far more costly to produce and far less effective than swarms of heavy bombers.

>>56246182
>Yes you do, that gun fires faster than any missile available to ground troops, stabilized guns are absolutely an asset when you’re properly using a tank.
There is a difference between what is necessary, and what is desirable if cost and resources is not an issue.

The original WW1 trenches were broken by vehicles with machineguns at 37mm gun. The ww2 Blitzkriegs ran on the back of 75mm stub guns on a Pz3. Modern blitz ran off vehicles like Abu Hajaa Armored trucks (that defeated a Abrams equipped force) or Humvees.

The one constant in history is that any vehicle that is small arms armored and can mount a gun will be pressed into combat. It happened with M113, it happened with humvee, it happens with with BMP and BTRs and everything categorized as technical.

Fire superiority and suppressing the hell out of the opponent is the key to success, and sufficient number of shitty vehicles can do the job just fine. Infantry is as fragile as ever, no need to upgrade weapons all that much as 50cal still works.

The drive in gun-armor competition comes from tank dueling, because everyone hates a Tiger II on a hill or Centurion or Abrams pwning your entire vehicle fleet.

If you have other means of killing tanks, from typhoons with rockets to brimestone spam, you don't need heavily armed and armored tanks for fire support.

In practice, with current tiny number tanks available, nations would have to resort to lighter vehicle with gun in practice when serious war breaks out.

not entirely true, RoF i part of the equation, not the whole, the idea is to get enough rounds on target to do enough damage to kill the target in the shortest amount of time

if one gun needs to score 30 hits to kill and one gun needs to score 5 hits to kill then the gun that only needs 5 hits can accept a rate of fire 6 times lower than one that needs 30 and still kill its target in the same interval


convergence zones etc mean that the hit probablity of a individual round fired out of say a corsair armed with either the 4 20mms or the 6 .50s was pretty much the same, the difference was that while the 6 .50s would put out 78 bullets a second between them the 20mms would put out 50 shells, the shells however would needs less than half as many hits to kill the target due to their significantly more destructive effect on impact.


rate of fire isnt the key, weight of metal on target in a given interval is the key, rate of fire is one way of achieving that, but not the only way and cannon offered a more weight efficient method of achieving the same end.

threads.com:
Previous >>56179383
New cover when edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

Entrenched infantry have no range or mobility but a LOT of HP. So infantry can block attacks from long range attackers for a longgggg time.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

Well for one infantry do actual assaulting. When you think about it, the reason all those systems like mortars, tanks, and air strikes exist is to dull the infantry’s offensive and defensive capability. So infantry’s role remains largely the same as it always has, only now they’re usually mechanized or at least motorized, and there’s a lot more counters to them.
What that means is, they assault and take and hold land, but require better assets and support to be successful against similarly equipped infantry and armor

Why don’t medium sized drones like the tb2 carry some air to air MANPADS. They are light enough to where the drone could carry a few. Here’s my reasoning

>increase range of the MANPADS
Say the drone is flying 3km high, it could engage targets that would normally be too high for surface launched MANPADS
>field of view
The drone would be able to see unimpeded in all directions
>mobility
A network of radars on the ground could link up to the drone and tell it where the threat is. The drone could move to within range of the threat and send a missile at it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56245230
>hy not drop the whole armor part then and just have a normal vehicle with a gigant gun on?
because removing armor is dumb
removing armor reduces total mobility as the crew has to drive more slowly and more carefully in combat to avoid being detected
low armor also means the force can be held in place with a weaker force
something only armored against .30cal can be held by a unit armed with HMGs, so you want the heaviest armor possible so that the enemy can only succesfully hold your force if they bring their own heavy weapons

>Besides, what it the point of that big tank-gun, besides shooting other tanks, that can't be done with artillery?
>literally doesnt understand the purpose of artillery within armored divisions
within US doctrine, artillery is the holding force and the tanks are the maneuver force
the artillery suppresses defenders and restricts their movement while the tanks then maneuver round to destroy the target, usually by encircling them

artillery is obviously too slow, too lightly armored, and with too little minimum range to effectively act as a maneuver unit

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56241749
>also how long can I keep shotgun shells lying around before they go bad?
decades if your storage conditions are good. about a year if they are bad for example i had a box of shells in the trunk of my car where 2/5 were duds after 2 years. i have no clue when exactly they went bad but its more i just acidentally left em in the trunk and didnt notice cause it moved under something. in a car you get drastic temperature differences over a year. its not a stable storage environment.

as for loaded in your shotgun you want to use that ammo after 6 months. if you leave it in there for a year spring pressure will compress and bulge the plastic shells slightly. its not a safety concern but those shells will take more force to chamber and could possible cause a jam if you werent expecting more resistance.
if its mag fed you really have to watch for shell deformation. that could happen in a week on some designs.
